Package edu.luc.cs.trull

Contains all the classes for building systems in Trull, a framework for concurrent programming with objects, threads, and events in Java.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Combinator A building block for building complex components from existing components.
Component A building block for a concurrent software system.
EventFunction A function from events to objects.
EventPredicate A function from events to boolean.
EventValuator A function from events to int.
PropertyChangeSource A source of PropertyChangeEvents.
Scheduler An abstraction of a centralized event processing thread such as the Swing event dispatch thread.
SchedulerAware Interface to be implemented by components that want to be aware of the (typically global) event scheduler.
Startable An abstraction of an activity that can be started and stopped.
Suspendable An abstraction of an activity that can be suspended and resumed.
Terminating A component that supports termination by notifying a TerminationListener.
TerminationListener A listener for termination of a Trull component.
TopLevelComponent A top-level Trull component whose lifecycle methods can be invoked without worrying about thread safety.
 

Class Summary
AbstractCombinator An abstract superclass for combinators with the ability to manage a list of Trull components.
AbstractComponent An abstract superclass for components.
ActionComponent An adapter for using a simple PropertyChangeListener as a Trull component.
AwaitAll A conjunctive await.
AwaitOne A disjunctive await.
BranchValuator An EventValuator suitable for branching on the label of an incoming event.
Composite The composition of zero or more concurrent components that communicate through PropertyChangeEvents.
Control A combinator that maps sets of events to a component's lifecycle methods start and stop.
Cycle A combinator that cycles round-robin among several components on any event from a given set of triggering events.
DefaultScheduler An implementation of the Scheduler interface based on Doug Lea's QueuedExecutor.
DefaultTopLevelComponent A top-level component wrapper implementation that combines a scheduler with an ordinary Trull component.
Done A basic component that does nothing and terminates immediately.
Emit A basic component for unconditional event emission.
EmitComponent A superclass or delegation support class for components that require preemptable and suspendable event emission.
EmptyComponent An empty Trull component implementation.
FastScheduler An implementation of the Scheduler interface based on Doug Lea's QueuedExecutor.
If A data-driven selection mechanism that evaluates its predicate and immediately chooses and starts the corresponding branch.
Local A combinator for hiding events within a component.
Loop A combinator that provides looping.
MethodForwardingSupport Method forwarding support for implementing Composite.
Nil A basic component does nothing but never terminates.
PropertyChangeMulticaster A multicaster for PropertyChangeEvents based on Doug Lea's efficient copy-on-write implementation but with the missing getPropertyChangeListeners methods added.
Rename A combinator for event renaming and event hiding.
Sequence A combinator for executing zero or more components in sequence.
SingleChildCombinator An abstract superclass for Trull combinators with a single child.
Suspend A combinator for mapping sets of events to a component's lifecycle methods suspend and resume.
Switch A data-driven selection mechanism that immediately evaluates its valuator (criterium) and chooses the corresponding branch.
TerminatingComponent An abstract superclass for components that signal termination to their parents in the component tree.
Util A class that provides utility methods used by the Trull framework.
Watching A combinator for event-based preemption.
 

Package edu.luc.cs.trull Description

Contains all the classes for building systems in Trull, a framework for concurrent programming with objects, threads, and events in Java. Trull supports the modular design of event-driven systems through combinators that operate on abstract behaviors.

An Trull software component combines three aspects of behavior:

  • object-oriented behavior based on methods and instance variables;
  • event-driven (reactive) behavior based on responses to events received from the environment;
  • autonomous behavior based on threads that evolve independently.

All three aspects of behavior may result in the emission of events to the surrounding system (the component's environment).

A class for a custom Trull component is usually declared by extending one of the classes that implement the interface Component and providing any necessary instance variables for the object-oriented aspects of the component. The event-driven aspects of the expression are usually provided in the constructor. The thread-based aspects are usually provided by implementing the lifecycle methods; specific support for such components is provided by the Trull Task framework.

Code that interacts with the object-oriented aspects of a Trull component may be embedded in the event-driven behavior in the form of embedded listeners, event functions, predicates, and valuators. Using combinators, complex components may be built hierarchically from existing components.
